It looks like Russians are facing a large shortage of groceries or an even greater rise in prices.  Russian Federal Antimonopoly Service plans to introduce a ban on increasing food prices in 2024 by more than 30% within 60 days. The corresponding bill, developed on behalf of Deputy Prime Minister Andrei Belousov, has already been sent to the government.  Large companies will be prohibited from raising prices by more than 30% for 60 days without an obvious reason - that is, if they cannot justify the increase with economic factors. Violators will first be given orders, the next step is to initiate a case. The goal is to stabilize food prices in Russia before the elections. The list of goods that the regulator will monitor will also be established by the government. Presumably, these will be the most socially significant products - meat, milk, eggs, bread, tea and others. Moreover, the anti-monopoly service will make a decision on unreasonable price increases based on data from the Ministry of Economic Development, the draft says.  At the same time, almost every fourth large company plans to increase prices to maintain operational efficiency, a new monitoring by the Russian Union of Entrepreneurs showed. In just one quarter, their share increased from 13.7 to 23%, becoming the highest since the spring of 2022. With this trend, before the end of the year, almost every company will raise prices. Among small companies, the percentage of those who plan to raise prices is many times greater.  But this is unlikely to keep prices down in Russia. After all, manufacturers have a lot of reasons to explain the growth - from the fall of the ruble and rising fuel prices to the rise in gas prices for industry. So it is unlikely that an artificial ban will keep prices low.

Older white man getting gas.  Man: I get angry every time I fill up.  Me: Why is that?  Man: The prices! When Trump was in office fuel was cheap! This is bullshit!  Me: Trump did that?  Man: Absolutely!  Me: (showing genuine interest):  How did he do it?  Man: Drill baby drill! American oil!  Me: I actually have family in the oil industry in Oklahoma. Trump actually asked the Saudis to increase production hurting the American oil industry. You know, the gas prices right now are just a few pennies more than when Trump left office, right?  Man: I don't know.  Me: Later he signed an agreement with the Saudis to restrict imports of oil, which caused gas prices to spike coming out of the pandemic.  Man: So you're a Biden guy, huh?  Me: No, I'm no politician's guy. I support what's right and true. I choose politicians that I believe will do the right thing for the right reasons.  Man: And you believe Biden is doing that?  Me: Yes. There's not a lot a President can do to impact gas prices, but the inflation reduction act did help. We know this because our fuel prices are much cheaper than most any other industrialized nation.  Man: I don't know if I believe that.  Me: Well, a belief isn't always a truth (smiling). Google it.  Man: (mumbles under his breath)  Me: Look, here are the facts, look them up. Gas was around $2.70 a gallon in 2019, right before the pandemic.  During the pandemic fuel consumption tanked, people were staying home.  Crude oil was actually selling on the market for a negative price.  As a result, gas prices dropped, going below $1 per gallon in 13 states in April of 2020. But jobs in the American oil industry dropped too!  American refineries either reduced or completely stopped production for a while.  As the pandemic waned, demand for fuel spiked as people return to work.  This was the beginning of inflation. Not just in fuel, but everything.  Man: You bet it was, just as Biden took office.  Me: True, but it's important to understand why.  Do you remember that lumber was high too?  Man: Yes, outrageously high!  Me: That's right, because the mills had shut down.  Do you remember what egg prices did?  Man: Through the roof!  Me: Yep, egg producers were slaughtering their chickens because they couldn't afford to feed them during the height of the pandemic. People weren't going to restaurants and eating eggs!  Man: I'm an old farmer, so that makes sense.  (We've long since finished filling up, but continue to have a friendly conversation).  Me: Look, it's important to put politics aside and look at the facts going in and then out of the pandemic.  As a pandemic grew, the pipeline of goods dwindled. As it waned, there was a pent-up demand and an increase in demand all at the same time. It took time to refill the supply line. This spiked prices!  Man: Did it ever!  Me: Remember all those container ships waiting to unload?  Man: Yes! Yes I do!  Me: But, look at what has happened since. Prices have steadily come down, even though a lot of corporations have kept their prices artificially high and reaped unbelievable profits. This is especially true of American oil companies.  Man: I heard something about that!  Me: But I will agree with you on one thing, Trump did, in fact, have a HUGE IMPACT on the big drop in fuel prices.  Man: Yes he did!  Me: But, he also greatly impacted all the inflation that followed!  Man: (a look of disbelief) How?  Me: By mismanaging the pandemic. His months of delays and denials worsened and lengthened its impact on everyone's live. It's estimated that he cost 750,000 Americans their lives!  Man: I don't believe that at all!  Me: you don't remember the denials? "It'll be gone by Easter!"?  Man: Yeah, I do remember that, and that bleach thing was stupid.  Me: Valuable time lost.  Man: (extended his hand to shake mine) I gotta go, but I did enjoy our talk!  Me: Me too! Merry Christmas!  Man: (Smiles) didn't think you guys said Merry Christmas!  Me: Don't believe everything you hear! (wink).

On my watch, we have achieved better growth and lower inflation than any other advanced country. A year ago, forecasters said it couldn't be done.  But I know prices are still too high. That's why my top economic priority is to lower costs for hardworking Americans.

3. Duration Risk: However, while rate cuts can initially raise bond prices, they also increase the risk of holding long-term bonds. If rates remain low for an extended period, the potential for higher future inflation might erode the purchasing power of the fixed coupon payments.

2. Yield Compression:  As interest rates decrease, the yield on new bonds also tends to decline. This might lead investors to seek higher yields offered by existing long-term bonds held within ETFs. Consequently, the demand for these ETFs could increase, pushing their prices up.

Lower interest rates make existing bonds with higher yields more attractive, thus increasing their demand and subsequently their prices. This relationship could potentially boost the value of long-term bond ETFs.

1. Bond Prices and Interest Rates: Long-term bond ETFs tend to have an inverse relationship with interest rates. When the Fed cuts rates, bond prices typically rise. At the moment sentiment is that there will be no new hikes, but that rates can stay higher for longer.

If Bonds confuse you, read this:  1) Bond prices are inversely related to bond yields  2) So when interest rates rise, bond prices fall. This is because investors can get a higher yield on new bonds, so they are willing to pay less for older bonds with lower interest rates.  3) And when interest rates fall, bond prices rise. This is because investors get a lower yield on new bonds, so they are willing to pay more for older bonds with higher interest rates.

Let me explain:   Hundreds of billions of taxpayer dollars are spent on research, discovery, and development of new prescription drugs. Seeing the reactions to this, I decided to talk a bit about how these valuations and prices are placed on houses.   There are different methods and approaches that real estate valuers use to conduct property valuations in Nigeria, such as:  1. The Comparison Method:  This method compares the property with similar properties that have been sold or rented in the same area within a reasonable time frame.   The valuer adjusts the prices of the comparable properties to account for differences in features, quality, and market conditions.   This method is commonly used for residential and commercial properties that have an active and competitive market.  2. The Income Method:  This method estimates the value of a property based on the income it can generate, either from rent, lease, or other sources.   The valuer calculates the net income of the property after deducting expenses and applies a capitalization rate to derive the present value.   This method is suitable for income-producing properties such as hotels, office buildings, shopping malls, etc.  3. The Cost Method:  This method measures the value of a property based on the cost of acquiring the land and constructing the building, plus depreciation and obsolescence.   The valuer considers the current replacement cost of the property and deducts the loss in value due to physical deterioration, functional inadequacy, or external factors.   This method is often used for special-purpose properties that have no comparable market data, such as schools, hospitals, churches, etc.  So, you may think the valuations are inflated, but in more ways than not, they can be justified.

Stocks in Asia Drop on Weak Oil, China Debt Woes - #Asia #MarketWrap - Following losses on Wall Street, shares throughout Asia declined as a result of low oil prices and worries about China's financial stability. After a spike, Treasury bonds fell as Japanese debt was liquidated. - Hong Kong, mainland China, and Australia had weaker equity values as the S&P 500 saw its third consecutive day of declines. US futures remained stable. - After falling to 4.1% on Wednesday, the lowest level since August, 10-year Treasury rates increased. The seven-basis-point increase followed a selloff in Japanese sovereign debt and represents a wider shift in attitude observed in Australian bonds as well. - Japan's 10-year yield ended a three-day fall on Thursday, rising as much as 10.5 basis points to 0.75%. Weak demand from a 30-year government paper auction added to the move's strength. The yen gained 0.5% versus the US dollar. - The declines in energy producers following the oil price's lowest point since June due to oversupply worries and concerns about China's debt load following Moody's Investors Service's downgrade of several local companies and its earlier downgrade of the country's sovereign bond outlook were the main causes of the equity market's weakness. - Hao Hong, chief economist at Grow Investment, said, "It is very surprising that Moody's has downgraded the outlook for a large number of Chinese companies." "After outlook downgrades, Moody's typically lowers the companies' rating within one to one and a half years, increasing their funding costs."

A dark pool is a private exchange where financial assets, like stocks or bonds, are traded away from public markets. It allows large investors to trade large blocks of securities anonymously, which can sometimes affect market prices less than trading on public exchanges. The trades in dark pools are not visible to the public until after they're executed, providing some privacy and reducing the impact on the broader market.

Financial market trends are the prevailing movements in the prices of stocks, bonds, commodities, and other financial instruments.  They can be driven by a variety of factors, including economic conditions, political events, and natural disasters.  By understanding the key financial market trends, investors can make more informed decisions about where to allocate their capital.  Some of the most important financial market trends to watch for include:  * **Economic growth:** The health of the economy is a major driver of financial market trends.  When the economy is growing, businesses tend to do well, which leads to higher stock prices.  Conversely, when the economy is struggling, businesses suffer, which can lead to lower stock prices.  * **Inflation:** Inflation is the rate at which prices are rising.  When inflation is high, it can erode the value of investments, such as stocks and bonds.  Conversely, when inflation is low, it can make investments more attractive.  * **Interest rates:** Int

This surge was part of a broad market rally, including stocks, loans, and emerging markets. Even speculative and high-risk assets like obscure cryptocurrencies saw significant gains.  The rally was a much-needed boost for bond investors, who faced potential losses for a third straight year. The Bloomberg US Aggregate Index jumped 4.9% as ten-year bond yields fell to 4.26%. The rally's future hinges on economic slowdown, inflation decline, and the Fed's halt in interest rate hikes.  Soft employment and consumer price data, coupled with dovish statements from the Fed, fueled bond market optimism. The MSCI World Index and emerging market stocks climbed significantly, and the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index rose by 18%.  In the credit sector, U.S. junk bonds and ETFs tracking them saw notable increases. Traders now anticipate monetary policy easing in 2024, with potential interest rate cuts as early as the Fed's May meeting.  A shift in market sentiment, spurred by the prospect of a soft economic landing and lower borrowing costs, prompted bond fund managers to invest in longer-term bonds. This strategy has been reflected in significant gains for certain funds, with expectations that the trend could continue if the Fed's policy shift becomes evident.

Understanding the mechanics of bonds is essential for any investor. One important aspect to note is the relationship between bond prices and bond yields.   Simply put, when interest rates go up, bond prices go down. This is because investors can obtain better returns from newer bonds, making them less willing to pay a higher price for older bonds with lower interest rates.   Conversely, when interest rates decrease, bond prices tend to increase as investors seek out higher yields and are willing to pay more for older bonds with higher interest rates. This inverse relationship is crucial to keep in mind when considering investing in bonds.

German inflation declined more than expected in November, owing to easing¬†energy and transport expenses, putting the European Central Bank's 2% objective within reach. Consumer prices increased 2.3% year on year, down from 3% in October.  German bonds extended their gains, with the two-year bond yield falling seven basis points on the day to 2.85%. The start of the rally came after Spain¬†reported¬†a comparable decline in inflation. Data for France, Italy, and the eurozone's 20 member countries are to be reported¬†on Thursday.   Although the numbers are encouraging for the ECB, they are not expected to lead policymakers to declare victory ahead of their last policy meeting of 2023. Inflation is still too high and has been for far too long President Christine Lagarde emphasized on Monday. The November data should persuade the ECB to keep interest rates unchanged at their next meeting. The December rebound combined with potential upside inflation risks in the upcoming months might heighten concerns about premature rate cuts by the central bank.

What you need to know about bonds now that they are the hottest assets for investors: 1) Bond prices are inversely related to bond yields. 2) When interest rates rise, bond prices fall because investors can get a higher yield on new bonds and are hence willing to pay less for older bonds with lower interest rates. 3) When interest rates fall, bond prices rise because investors get a lower yield on new bonds and are therefore willing to pay more for older bonds with higher interest rates. Advise: invest in government bonds today, rates are at an all time high.

Rising interest rates can have a significant impact on bond investing. When interest rates increase, the value of bonds decreases, as investors can earn higher returns from new bonds with higher interest rates. This is known as interest rate risk. As a result, the prices of existing bonds with lower interest rates will fall, making them less attractive to investors. This can lead to a decrease in demand and an increase in supply, further driving down prices. However, longer-term bonds will be affected more than shorter-term bonds, as they are more sensitive to changes in interest rates. The impact of rising interest rates on bond investing also depends on the type of bond. For example, government bonds are considered safer investments, so their prices may not be as affected compared to riskier corporate bonds. It is important for investors to closely monitor interest rate changes and consider diversifying their portfolio to mitigate the impact of rising interest rates on their bond investments.

Is the decline in bond yields reflected in stock prices?  U.S. government bond yields have corrected from a peak of 5%, raising questions about corresponding stock valuations. Stock prices are influenced by four key variables, including two estimable factors: risk premiums and future growth. For instance, if bond yields rise to 5% but are accompanied by an increase in nominal economic and profit growth, stock valuations might not decrease. Additionally, the complex interplay between bond yields and stock valuations often involves other significant factors, particularly in the current market scenario.

The forecast is based on upgraded bond yield forecasts and the loosening of housing markets in B.C. and Ontario.  Other regions in Canada have benefited from tighter markets and better affordability.  Ontario's sales-to-new-listings ratio fell to 39% in October due to a sudden surge in supply.  Despite the downward revision, average home prices would still be 15% higher than pre-pandemic levels.  In October, the average home price in Canada was $757,600.

A Primer on Japan's economic woes:  In March 2022, the Fed aggressively raised interest rates from ~0% to the current 5.5%.  The higher interest rates from the Fed led to a crash in bond prices (resulting in an increase in their yields). Below is a chart comparing the 10-Year US Treasury (UST) and the 10-Year Japanese Government Bond (JGB).  The spread between the two curves has widened significantly in recent years due to the Fed's interest rate hikes in the US.  Yields on the 10-Year Japanese debt are significantly lower than in the US because the Bank of Japan (BOJ) manipulates rates through Yield Curve Control (YCC) on the 10-Year JGB.  Under YCC, the BOJ sets a target yield for the 10-Year JGB, historically aiming for a range of 0% to 0.1%. They allow JGBs to fluctuate within that range and buy/sell if it goes above/below their target range. With YCC, the BOJ can purchase virtually unlimited amounts of 10-Year JGBs to support their mandate and hold them on their balance sheet.  With JGB yields set low, investors have little incentive to hold these bonds, currently yielding only 0.5% to 1%, compared to the 4.7% yield on the 10-Year US Treasury.  In other words, investors are selling low-yielding JGBs in favor of higher-yielding debt, such as US Treasuries. The selling of Japanese debt has caused the Japanese Yen to weaken significantly compared to the US dollar.  As the Japanese Yen weakens, the USD/JPY exchange rate has reached multi-decade highs, surpassing the psychologically significant level of 150.  Japan is starting to crack Weakening Yen A weak yen poses challenges for the Japanese economy, as Japan relies on imports to meet its crucial food and energy needs. The country does not produce enough of these goods domestically, and a weak yen leads to higher prices for energy and food for Japanese individuals and businesses.  Consequently, Japanese policymakers fear that the weakening yen could result in excessively high food and energy prices, disrupting the functioning of the economy.  When energy and food prices are too high, an economy cannot function properly and may eventually come to a standstill.  Japan's massive debt When the BOJ conducts YCC, it continuously increases Japan's debt burden by essentially buying limitless amounts of Japanese debt, effectively created out of thin air.  YCC has caused Japan's debt-to-GDP ratio to inflate to a massive 267%, with the Bank of Japan alone holding 52% of that debt.  Since JGBs are just debt owed by the government, higher interest rates mean higher servicing costs for that debt that must be paid by the Japanese government.  Despite artificially keeping bond yields low through yield curve control, 23% of Japan's 2022 budget was allocated to service the national debt.  There is limited room to raise interest rates in Japan due to the massive debt load, and doing so would exacerbate the already alarming debt problem. The budget lacks space for increased spending to service the national debt.  So, spending 23% of the budget to service debt is bad, it gets even worse when Japan is forced to raise interest rate targets for its YCC, as it has in recent months.  As I mentioned earlier, the BOJ has historically targeted 0%-0.1% on the 10 year JBG for its YCC, however it has recently been forced to raise those targets in an attempt to stop the weakening of the Yen.  Japan is stuck between a rock and a hard place.  High interest rates in the US create problems for Japan.  Japan has been forced to raise yield targets for its YCC program to slow the weakening of the Yen. However, this action results in higher financing costs for the Japanese government, which cannot afford these costs without taking on additional debt, furthering the debt spiral.  Even with the increased targets for its YCC policy, the Yen continues to decline against the USD. Further adjustments to YCC will be necessary to halt the Yen's slide.  On the other hand, energy and food are primary inputs for the economy. If the BOJ takes no action to prevent the weakening of the Yen, high energy and food prices could push Japan's economy into a depression.

Reason why to trade Gold or $GC  Diversification: Gold often has a low or negative correlation with other asset classes like stocks and bonds. This means when the stock market declines, gold prices might remain stable or even increase. Including gold in an investment portfolio can thus help in diversifying risks.  Inflation Hedge: Gold is widely regarded as an effective hedge against inflation. When the value of a currency decreases due to inflation, gold prices often increase. This is because gold retains its value better than many paper currencies or financial assets.  Safe Haven Asset: In times of economic uncertainty or geopolitical instability, investors often turn to gold as a safe haven asset. Its value is perceived as being more stable over the long term, compared to other assets that might be more volatile or subject to market whims.  Currency Fluctuations: Gold can also be used as a hedge against currency fluctuations, particularly in the forex market. Since gold is priced in U.S. dollars, it can be a strategic asset for investors holding currencies that might depreciate against the dollar.  ‚úçÔ∏èThe one I prefer here below! Market Uncertainty and Volatility: During periods of high market volatility or uncertainty, such as during economic recessions or crises, gold is sought after for its perceived stability.  @AnthonyCrudele

2 things stand out in this chart. First this is a chart of the 30 yr, 10 yr, 1 yr & 3 month t-bill interest rates from 12/31/1979. Second, understand that bond prices rise when rates fall.   2020 is the first/only  time in the 44 years of this chart when the rates for ALL these maturities converge on zero. In 2008, the 30 yr & 10 yr interest rates were robustly positive even as the Fed crushed short term rates. From being in that market, I remember persistent panic about hyperinflation. And you can see spikes in the 30 yr & 10 yr rate in 2010, 2011 and 2013. This occurred as the US and world economy teetered at/near deflation.  The Fed was hoovering up every bond it could find to spread liquidity as far and wide as possible.   So, the bond market making a wrong way bet on lower rates even as the Fed (and inflation, employment, consumer spending, GDP etc) points to higher for longer is not out of character.   One more thing to point out thats different now. If you look at the chart, you'll see one big difference in this rate cycle. Long rates are lagging short rates higher leaving a inverted yield curve in place for nearly 2 years now. 2 years? With no recession or crisis or crash. Hmmm. üßêü§îü§® Yeah, something is different this time around. I believe its the cumulative effect of Fed's ZIRP/QE (quantitative easing) and the astonishing spending binge of the US govt in the pandemic. There is way too much money in the system. This is why even after 2 years of rates rising, QT (quantitative tightening) there is no recession, crisis, crash. Its business as usual. Bond buyers are looking back in hope at the last 14 years and wishing for it to come back. But, all the signals point to higher for longer, no disaster, no recession, no crisis, no crash and most importantly no cuts from the Fed.  In my opinion, rates stay in and around current levels for a long time.

‚Ä¢ Short-term bonds: Follow the usual inverse relationship between yields and prices.  ‚Ä¢ Long-term bonds: The relationship is more intricate, influenced by factors like future economic expectations affecting demand and prices.

However, in an inverted yield curve, predicting bond prices is complex. Investors consider not only interest rates but also the economic outlook. During an expected recession, they might pay more for bonds, even with rising rates.

Bond prices vary based on demand: If interest rates go up, bond prices drop. Investors seek higher yields on new bonds, so they pay less for existing ones. If interest rates fall, bond prices rise. Investors accept lower yields on new bonds, leading them to pay more.

Understanding Bonds (Bonds 101):  Typically, bond prices and yields move in opposite directions, but things get interesting with an inverted yield curve (where short-term bond yields surpass long-term ones).

The collapse of the Producer Price Index (PPI) and the restrictions on companies charging excessive prices or making substantial profits, coupled with the inability to refinance at low-interest rates and the lack of Federal Reserve support for their bonds, can be considered bearish for the S&P 500 for several reasons:  Earnings Decline: When companies cannot charge higher prices or generate excessive profits, their earnings potential diminishes. This could negatively impact stock prices, as investors often value companies based on their earnings.  Financial Strain: Inability to refinance debt at lower rates could strain the financial health of companies, potentially leading to credit issues or even bankruptcies. This uncertainty and financial instability can cause stock prices to decline.  Reduced Market Confidence: If the Federal Reserve is not supporting companies by buying their bonds, it might signal a lack of confidence in those companies. This lack of backing can erode market confidence, leading to investor hesitation and potential sell-offs.  Economic Slowdown: Constraints on pricing power and profitability could indicate a broader economic slowdown or contraction, which generally isn't favorable for stock markets. Slower economic growth can lead to reduced corporate earnings and dampen investor sentiment.  Market Correction: A combination of these factors could trigger a market correction or downturn as investors reevaluate the valuation of companies facing constrained profits and financial challenges.  #PPI #inflation $SPY $SPX

Due to weak demand for the T-30 Bonds the Yield went up. if you wonder why, here is a simple explanation: Weak demand for 30-year Treasury bonds means fewer investors are buying them. When there's less demand for a bond, its price drops. Bond prices and yields have an inverse relationship: when the price of a bond decreases, its yield increases. So, weak demand leads to lower prices and consequently higher yields for those bonds.

Brent Below $80 - #US #MarketWrap - Stocks rose slightly in the final hour of trading, as traders awaited Jerome Powell's remarks to see if he would dampen Wall Street's dovish narrative. Bond prices increased during a busy week for debt sales. - While the pace of the equity rally slowed, the S&P 500 posted its eighth straight positive day. Despite mixed metrics, US 10-year yields fell to around 4.5% after a $40 billion auction, with a slightly higher-than-anticipated rate of 4.519%: a sign that demand fell short of expectations. Thirty-year rates fell to their lowest level in over a month. Brent crude fell below $80 per barrel. - Treasury sales are increasingly influencing stock prices. According to Citigroup Inc. data, the S&P 500 has moved about 1% in either direction on auction days since the beginning of 2022, far exceeding the prior decade's average. Their research puts traders on high alert ahead of Thursday's $24 billion sale of 30-year bonds. - Wall Street is also paying close attention to Fedspeak. Powell did not comment on the outlook for interest rates in a brief statement on Wednesday. He'll have more time to express himself on Thursday during a panel discussion on monetary policy challenges. - The current level of the Fed's benchmark rate - 5.25% to 5.5% - is expected to be the peak of the tightening cycle, according to swap traders.

Cooling yields and oil prices helped the S&P 500 and Nasdaq have their longest winning streak in two years All three main US stock indexes increased for the 7th consecutive day after bond yields and oil prices cooled. According to CNBC, in the trading session on November 7, the Dow Jones industrial average increased 57 points, equivalent to 0.17%, to 34,153 points. The S&P 500 index increased 0.28%, closing the session with 4,378 points. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite index rose 0.9% to close at 13.40 points. At the end of the last session, the S&P 500 recorded a 7-day winning streak, the longest since an 8-day streak in November 2021. At the same time, the Nasdaq Composite had 8 consecutive days of increases for the first time since a streak of 11 days also in November 2021. The Dow Jones index went up for the 7th consecutive session, marking the longest series of positive trading sessions since July. Similar to the general market movements, VinFast (VFS) shares increased 0.41% to 6.16 USD/share. With this result, VinFast's capitalization reached 14.4 billion USD, ranking 28th in the list of the world's largest car manufacturers.  During the November 7 session, technology stocks increased in price when the yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds turned down again. As of the evening of November 7, this yield had dropped to 4.573%. Amazon and Salesforce shares rose more than 2%, while Apple, Microsoft and Meta (Facebook) rose about 1%. Shares of semiconductor companies Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Broadcom and Intel also rose as funding from the CHIPS Act was set to be distributed.  "When yields fall, growth stocks tend to recover stronger," said Ms. Mona Mahajan, senior investment strategist at Edward Jones. In addition, she also added that cooling oil prices also contributed to the market's recovery.  ‚ÄúThere was some momentum from last week, some came later,‚Äù Ms. Mahajan said. ‚Äú[But] we have not seen any real support for the upward momentum over the past 6 days.‚Äù  In addition, in the November 7 session, Datadog shares jumped 28.5% after exceeding business results forecasts as well as giving a positive outlook. Uber shares rose 3.7% even as third-quarter profits did not meet expectations. High interest rates in the US are causing Japan to crack  In March 2022, the Fed initiated aggressive interest rate hikes, raising interest rates from ~0% to the current 5.5%.  The higher interest rates from the Fed led to a crash in bond prices(an increase in their yields). Below is a chart comparing the 10-Year US Treasury (UST) and the 10-Year Japanese Government Bond (JGB). The spread between the two curves has widened significantly in recent years as the Fed raised interest rates in the US.  Yields on the 10-Year Japanese debt are significantly lower than in the US because the Bank of Japan (BOJ) manipulates the rates on the 10-Year JGB through Yield Curve Control (YCC).  Under YCC, the BOJ sets a target yield for the 10-Year JGB, historically aiming for a range of 0% to 0.1%. They allow the JGBs to fluctuate within that range and buy/sell if it goes above/below their target range. Under YCC, the BOJ can purchase virtually unlimited amounts of 10-Year JGBs to support their mandate and park them on their balance sheet.  With JGB yields set low, investors have little incentive to hold these bonds, which currently yield only 0.5% to 1%, compared to the 10-Year US Treasury's 4.7%.  In other words, investors are selling low-yielding JGBs in favor of higher-yielding debt, such as US Treasuries. The selling of Japanese debt has caused the Japanese Yen to weaken significantly compared to the US dollar.  With the Japanese Yen weakening, the USD/JPY exchange rate has reached multi-decade highs, surpassing the psychologically significant level of 150.  Japan is starting to crack A weak yen causes problems A weak yen hurts the Japanese economy as Japan relies on imports to meet its vital food and energy needs. Japan does not produce enough of these goods domestically, and a weak yen drives up the prices of energy and food for Japanese individuals and businesses.  For this reason, Japanese policymakers fear that the weakening Yen could lead to excessively high food and energy prices, which can disrupt the functioning of the economy.  When energy and food prices are too high, an economy cannot function properly and may eventually come to a standstill.  Japan's debt causes problems When the BOJ conducts YCC, it continuously increases Japan's debt burden because it essentially buys limitless amounts of Japanese debt, which is effectively created out of thin air.  YCC has caused Japan's debt-to-GDP ratio to inflate to a massive 267%, with the Bank of Japan alone holding 52% of that debt.  Since JGBs are just government debt, higher interest rates translate to higher servicing costs for that debt, which must be paid by the Japanese government.  Despite artificially keeping bond yields low through yield curve control, 23% of Japan's 2022 budget was allocated to service the national debt.  There is limited room to raise interest rates in Japan because of the massive debt load, and doing so would exacerbate the already alarming debt problem. There is no room in the budget for increased spending to service the national debt.  So, allocating 23% of the budget to service debt is concerning, and it becomes even more problematic when the BOJ is forced to raise interest rate targets for its YCC program, as it has done in recent months.  As mentioned earlier, the BOJ historically targeted 0% to 0.1% for the 10-Year JGB in its YCC program, but it has been forced recently to raise those targets to 0.5% to 1%, where it stands today, in an attempt to halt the Yen's weakening.  Japan is stuck between a rock and a hard place.  High interest rates in the US create a problems for Japan.  Japan has been compelled to raise yield targets for its YCC program to counteract the weakening of the Yen, but this leads to higher financing costs for the Japanese government, which cannot afford these expenses without taking on additional debt, exacerbating the debt spiral.  Even with the increased targets for its YCC policy, the Yen continues to decline against the USD. Further adjustments to YCC will be necessary in order to halt the Yen's slide.  On the other hand, energy and food are the primary inputs for the economy. If the BOJ takes no action to prevent the weakening of the Yen, high energy and food prices could push Japan into an economic depression.

The rise in bond yields is now slowing again and asset prices will benefit short term, but will it be enough to fuel a sustainable rally?  I thought this is a good time to remind everyone that real sustainable accumulation for long-term investing in stocks begins when bond yields fall or at least stop rising for an extended period while stocks fall or move sideways - these usually mark the moments of maximum opportunity.  It is important to always look at bond yields in the context of the ongoing trends in the stock markets - that's why I wanted to share this chart - stagnating or falling yields and nice buying opportunities are what we should be prepared for in 2024.  The chart shows the relationship between bond yields (white line / volatility-adjusted & inverted) and the US stock market (red line) over the past 10 years.  ‚ñ∂Ô∏è The momentum of the US stock market is currently fairly low (red line) - it actually hit bottom levels last week and respectively the inverted momentum average of bond yields (white line) is also relatively low (which means yields are relatively high and might start to trend sideways or down soon / I can imagine one more irresponsible push higher in Q2 2024 to create a buying opportunity, but after that the rate hike cycle should be over). That's nothing new so far, but it helps with managing expectations.  ‚ñ∂Ô∏è From 2008 to 2021 stock market momentum (red line) and inverted bond yields (white line) were negatively correlated - the trend in yields was mostly leading the stock market by about 1 year and yields were a good indicator to predict the trend in the stock markets. This dynamic changed in 2021, inverted yields (white line) went down alongside the stock market momentum and the inverted momentum for yields did not yet cross over the stock market momentum which means real yields kept rising and markets kept slowing down.  We did not yet see bond yields having any lasting "supportive" influence on stocks in 2022 or 2023. On the contrary - stocks got crushed by the fast rate hikes.  But the two momentum lines are getting close now and a crossover could happen soon. A period of sustainable accumulation for stocks could. I disagree with this thesis. First, the Fed is doing $95B/ month in QT ($60B treasuries, $35B MBS), not $55B. Second, rates coming down doesn't guarantee higher stock prices unless the Fed is the buyer of bonds. In this case, those bonds are being bought by a shrinking pool of liquidity which at a point means money has to flow from equities and other risk assets into bonds to support the higher bond prices. Third, Yellen shared plans to issue $2B less in long-dated treasuries than expected. $2B over a quarter. The Fed offsets that in QT daily across the maturity curve. Finally, on reverse repo: this being drained isn't QE. Banks were parking cash at the Fed in exchange for short term treasuries. Now they're just buying the treasuries themselves bc they're getting a better return. The cash is still tied up for the same very short-term duration.

A non-orchestrated short squeeze in bonds is when a lot of investors who bet that bond prices would fall (by "shorting" them) suddenly realize they were wrong. This can happen when the bond prices start rising, and these investors rush to buy bonds to cover their bets, driving prices even higher. It's not planned or coordinated like some short squeezes in stocks, but it can still lead to a big, unexpected surge in bond prices.

Spot gold contracts maintained their level at $1,981.69 per ounce, while US gold futures increased by 0.1% to $1,989.20 per ounce.  The US dollar index declined, and the 10-year US treasury bond yield approached its three-week low, making gold more attractive. Bob Haberkorn, a senior market strategist at RJO Futures, stated, "Gold strengthens when there are cracks in the US labor market, which could signal the Fed's halt to interest rate increases."  Data showed a modest increase in weekly jobless claims in the US, as the labor market continued to exhibit significant signs of slowing down.  The Fed decided to keep interest rates unchanged on Wednesday as policymakers assessed whether financial conditions were tight enough to control inflation.  According to CME Group's FedWatch tool, the market currently discounts an 85% likelihood of the Fed keeping interest rates steady in December.  The market will also closely monitor the US non-farm payroll report on Friday for further insights into the Federal Reserve's monetary policy direction. Is the golden "avoidance era" opening?  However, in the stage of rapid rise in real interest rates of U.S. bonds last year and the second quarter of this year, even with the support of geopolitical conflicts and the central bank, gold prices still suffered obvious downward pressure, with a maximum decline of 20% and 10% respectively.  Therefore, if we want to use gold as part of asset allocation, we ultimately need to pay attention to the macro-cyclical factors that drive gold prices, such as real interest rates, economic growth, inflation, monetary policy and the US dollar.  As a zero-interest asset, the biggest opponent of gold is still the real interest rate of U.S. bonds. Even if the short-term correlation weakens in the short term, it is still impossible to "spent ways" in the long run.  At present, as the real interest rate remains high and may even continue to rise, gold, as a zero-interest asset, will continue to be under pressure. The world's largest gold financial asset is long, and the gold position of SPDR has dropped to 860 tons, a four-year low.  Of course, it may be difficult to maintain such a high real interest rate for too long. If the United States starts to cut interest rates in 2024, will this further form a trending support for gold prices?  The key is whether the premium of gold brought by the demand for risk aversion will gradually disappear.  That is to say, will we enter a more "risk-averse era" or a "risk era" in the future?  This issue is controversial even within policy institutions and financial institutions.  On the one hand, inflation is being controlled as the biggest risk to the global economy after the epidemic. On the other hand, the market is still worried about the risks that may be caused by the degree of recession and rapid austerity.  However, from the current situation, the United States has been calling for a recession since the beginning of the year, and the growth is still accelerating. The year-on-year ratio of U.S. real GDP in the third quarter was 4.9%, which rose significantly and better than expected. It is surprising that commodity consumption spending in the United States remains strong, and sales of new houses have also exceeded expectations.  This shows that the growth momentum of the U.S. economy, as a locomotive, is still very strong. Even if the market has always expected that the marginal growth rate of demand will slow down in the future, the slowdown is still much better than expected with the support of the job market and consumption.  China increased stability, Europe suspended interest rate hikes, and Japan withdrew in an orderly manner. At the same time, under the increase of the loose policy, China has gradually entered the end of de-libreasing, and the economy is likely to bottom out. The European Central Bank has pressed the pause button for raising interest rates or entered a more moderate recession, and the easing of inflation is also driving a slight rebound in economic activity. Japan's economy has achieved three quarter-on-quarter growth, and the YCC policy is also withdrawing in a further orderly manner.  Judging from the growth prospects of the top five economies, there seems to be insufficient evidence to enter a new era of more risk aversion in the future.  Of course, no one knows whether the conflict in the Middle East will escalate, whether there will be new geopolitical conflicts, or a new Silicon Valley banking incident.  Leaving aside these sudden factors, gold is no longer cheap at present. According to the calculation of brokerage research reports, its relative long-term pricing model price has been overestimated by about 33%.  Is $2,000 per ounce the high point of gold or the new starting point of gold? Is it the era of risk aversion or the era of risk? Conversely, when market interest rates fall, the prices of existing bonds rise because they become more attractive with their fixed interest rates compared to newer bonds with lower yields.

Bond prices and market interest rates are intertwined.   As market interest rates rise, the price of existing bonds with lower fixed rates tends to drop to make them more competitive with newer bonds.  Because investors will pay less for older bonds with lower interest rates.

3. Financial Stability Concerns: Large net short positions in Treasuries can pose risks to financial stability. If yields were to suddenly drop (bond prices rise), leveraged funds with significant short positions could face substantial losses. Such a scenario can trigger margin calls and forced liquidations, exacerbating market volatility.

Real-world assets (RWAs) should be priced in $SPOT  Here's why:  Being inflation-resistant, SPOT will automatically track CPI over time  This will provide valuations to RWAs (like bonds, commodities, real estate, etc.) in real terms, meaning prices aren't distorted due to fiat inflation  If assets are priced using SPOT, then smart contracts can be designed with inflation already accounted for. This accurately prices assets while the currency appreciates over time, protecting investor purchasing power.  For consumers, especially those in countries with high inflation, their purchasing power erodes rapidly. If goods and services were priced in SPOT, it would provide a more stable understanding of what their money can buy over time.

China üá®üá≥ is selling a significant amount of US government bonds üá∫üá∏, and with interest rates at their current high, the likelihood of incurring losses is there, but why sell now?  Firstly, the relationship between interest rates and bond prices is inversely correlated, and selling many bonds leads to lower bond prices and higher interest rates, and today the US 10-year bonds are at their highest in 16 years.  The 10-year bond interest rate directly affects mortgage rates, car loans, etc., and indirectly contributes to a slowdown in the economy.  The reason why China is selling bonds now is known only to them, but there are a few hypotheses:  1- If you're inclined to conspiracy theories, you might think they're doing it on purpose to cause a financial crash in the US. However, what does China gain from this, especially when the US imports a lot of goods from China, and China itself is facing the risk of a recession? Furthermore, selling now means they're at a loss.  2- China might need the money for something, possibly to use it to buy Chinese Yuan as the exchange rate with USD has not been favorable for years.  3- They may be concerned about the US defaulting, although the likelihood of default is almost non-existent when the Fed can print money.  4- It could simply be an effort to rebalance the national assets. üí∞üìâ  #China #USGovernmentBonds #InterestRates #EconomicStrategy

The reasons behind China's bond sell-off are known only to them, but there are several hypotheses:  1- If you are inclined towards conspiracy theories, you might think they are intentionally causing a financial downturn in the US. However, in doing so, what does China stand to gain, especially considering the significant amount of imports the US receives from China and China's own risk of recession? Furthermore, selling now would result in losses.  2- China may need the money for something, possibly for buying the Chinese $Yuan as its exchange rate against the $USD has not been favorable in recent years.  3- They might be concerned about the US defaulting, although the likelihood of this is low since the Federal Reserve can print money.  4- It could simply be a move to rebalance the national assets.  What do you think?

#CryptoNews #cryptocurrency  China's significant sale of U.S. government bonds, combined with the current high-interest rates, raises questions about the motivations behind this move. The relationship between interest rates and bond prices is inverse, meaning that when a large volume of bonds is sold, it tends to push bond prices down and yields (interest rates) up. Currently, the yield on the 10-year U.S. #Treasury bond is at its highest level in 16 years.  The interest rate on the 10-year #Treasury bond directly influences rates on mortgages, auto loans, and more, which can indirectly slow down economic activity.  While the exact reasons for China's bond sales may not be clear, several hypotheses have been put forward:  1. **Conspiracy Theorists**: Some may speculate that China is intentionally trying to trigger a financial downturn in the U.S. However, this raises the question of what China gains from such a scenario. China is a major exporter to the U.S., and a U.S. economic downturn could harm its own economy. Additionally, selling at a loss doesn't seem to be a beneficial strategy.  2. **Need for Funds**: China may require funds for a specific purpose, potentially related to its efforts to stabilize or strengthen its own economy. This could include bolstering the Renminbi due to unfavorable exchange rates with the U.S. dollar.  3. **Concerns About U.S. Debt**: There might be concerns in China about the level of U.S. debt, even though the risk of default is extremely low given the ability of the Federal Reserve to print money. Selling bonds could be seen as a hedge against this perceived risk.  4. **Portfolio Diversification**: It could be a simple move to rebalance China's national assets, possibly shifting from U.S. bonds to other types of assets for diversification purposes.  The exact reasons behind China's actions may remain a subject of debate and analysis among economists and financial experts.

A relentless selloff in U.S. government bonds has brought Treasury yields to their highest level in more than a decade and a half, roiling everything from stocks to the real estate market.  The yield on the benchmark 10 year Treasury - which moves inversely to prices - hit 5% late Thursday, a level last seen in 2007. Expectations that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates elevated and mounting U.S. fiscal concerns are among the fators driving the move.  Because the $25-trillion Treasury market is considered the bedrock of the global financial system, soaring yields on U.S. government bonds have had wide-ranging effects. The S&P 500 is down about 7% from its highs of the year, as the promise of guaranteed yields on U.S. government debt draws investors away from equities. Mortgage rates, meanwhile, stand at more than 20-year highs, weighing on real estate prices.  "Investors have to take a very hard look at risky assets," said Gennadiy Goldberg, head of U.S. rates strategy at TD Securities in New York. "The longer we remain at higher interest rates, the more likely something is to break."  Fed Chairman Jerome Powell on Thursday said monetary policy does not feel "too tight," bolstering the case for those who believe interest rates are likely to stay elevated.  Powell also nodded to the "term premium" as a driver for yields. The term premium is the added compensation investors expect for owning longer term debt and is measured using financial models. Its rise was recently cited by one Fed president as a reason why the Fed may have less need to raise rates.  Here is a look at some of the ways rising yields have reverberated throughout markets.  Higher Treasury yields can curb investors' appetite for stocks and other risky assets by tightening financial conditions as they raise the cost of credit for companies and individuals.  Elon Musk warned that high interest rates could sap electric-vehicle demand, which knocked shares of the sector on Thursday. Tesla‚Äôs shares closed the day down 9.3%, as some analysts questioned whether the company can maintain the runaway growth that has for years set it apart from other automakers.  With investors gravitating to Treasuries, where some maturities currently offer far above 5% to investors holding the bonds to term, high-dividend paying stocks in sectors such as utilities and real estate have been among the worst hit.  The U.S. dollar has advanced an average of about 6.4% against its G10 peers since the rise in Treasury yields accelerated in mid-July. The dollar index, which measures the buck‚Äôs strength against six major currencies, stands near an 11-month high. A stronger dollar helps tighten financial conditions and can hurt the balance sheets of U.S. exporters and multinationals. Globally, it complicates the efforts of other central banks to tamp down inflation by pushing down their currencies. For weeks, traders have been watching for a possible intervention by Japanese officials to combat a sustained depreciation in the yen, down 12.5% against the dollar this year.  "The correlation of the USD with rates has been positive and strong during the current policy tightening cycle," BofA Global Research strategist Athanasios Vamvakidis said in a note on Thursday.  The interest rate on the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage - the most popular U.S. home loan - has shot to the highest since 2000, hurting homebuilder confidence and pressuring mortgage applications. In an otherwise resilient economy featuring a strong job market and robust consumer spending, the housing market has stood out as the sector most afflicted by the Fed's aggressive actions to cool demand and undercut inflation.  U.S. existing home sales dropped to a 13-year low in September.  As Treasury yields surge, credit market spreads have widened with investors demanding a higher yield on riskier assets such as corporate bonds. Credit spreads blew out after a banking crisis this year, then they narrowed in subsequent months.  The rise in yields, however, has taken the ICE BofA High Yield Index near a four-month high, adding to funding costs for prospective borrowers.  Volatility in U.S. stocks and bonds has bubbled up in recent weeks as expectations have shifted for Fed policy. Anticipation of a surge in U.S. government deficit spending and debt issuance to cover those expenditures has also unnerved investors.  The MOVE index, measuring expected volatility in U.S. Treasuries, is near its highest in more than four months. Volatility in equities has also picked up, taking the Cboe Volatility Index to a five-month peak.

3Ô∏è‚É£ BANK MANDATED SALE   This is a process whereby the bond holder voluntarily hand over the property to the bank  to sell on their behalf when they are unable to keep up with monthly repayments.  The prices of property in Bank-Mandated sales are often fair & market-related.  The bondholder however has the right to decline an offer to purchase as in any commercial transaction.  However, if they refuse or are unable to sell the property,   the bank may eventually instigate legal proceedings & so they often consider reasonable offers.  Its a win for all.

Treasurys as an Inflation Hedge. Historically, U.S. Treasurys, particularly longer-term bonds, have been considered a relatively safe investment. However, they may not provide effective protection against inflation because their yields can be eroded by rising prices. When inflation expectations increase, the value of fixed-interest securities like Treasurys may decrease. Stocks, on the other hand, are often seen as a better hedge against inflation over the long term.

Best ways to lose money while trading treasuries/bonds:  ‚úÖ Owning a bond when the inflation rate is higher than the yield of the bond.  ‚úÖ After you purchase a bond, interest rates rise, (bond prices fall), and then you sell the bond before maturity for less than you paid.  ‚úÖ You buy a bond for 4-5% return, and lose the chance to invest or spend that money elsewhere for a better return (opportunity cost).  ‚úÖ You buy a bond but then the issuer of the bond decides to default or fails to pay interest or principal on time, thereby devaluing the bond or else rendering it worthless. A bond's "yield" is the interest paid on a bond.  Bond yields have an inverse relationship with bond prices.  Increased interest rates is leading to instability in the financial system.  When market interest rates increase, previously issued bonds decrease in market price because new investors prefer to buy newly issued bonds with higher interest payments.  For example, if you were in the market to buy $1,000 of bonds and you had 2 choices, which would you pick:  Bond 1: 2% yield Bond 2: 6% yield  If the prices for both were the same, any rational investor would prefer Bond 2.  This means demand for Bond 2 increases and demand for Bond 1 decreases.  Sometimes, bondholders become desperate to sell their bonds because they are in immediate need of cash.  This could mean the market becomes flooded with bonds for sale.  When demand decreases but supply remains constant or increases, price decreases.  Over the last year and a half, the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) has increased the Fed Funds Rate (the lowest interest rate to borrow US Dollars) from 0.25-0.50% to 5.25-5.50% in an attempt to fight inflation.  This has led to bond yields skyrocketing.  Before these rate increases, banks used customer deposits to buy bonds at low yields.  Those bonds have lost 40-50% of their value (due to rising rates).  Banks currently have massive unrealized losses on their balance sheets (they haven't sold their bonds yet).q  If banks receive too many withdrawal requests, they may not be able to fulfill the requests.  This could lead to trust in the financial system fading away and can lead to a complete collapse in the global financial system.  To avoid this, the Federal Reserve may eventually be forced to step in to buy those bonds at face value with newly issued money so regional banks can satisfy withdrawal requests.  This is what may happen to the US banking system in the near future.  It's only a matter of time before the Federal Reserve is forced to step in to buy bonds that have lost significant value to protect the financial system.  This is NOT how it should work.  The financial system is a house of cards, and it relies on depositors leaving their money deposited.  As more people learn about investing and want to buy assets instead of leaving their money in a bank account, the financial system will become more unstable.  Individual depositors can make or break the financial system!

US stock and bond prices fell on Thursday after disappointing inflation data and a weak government debt auction. The yield on the 10-year Treasury, which rises when prices fall, jumped 0.1 percentage points to 4.70 per cent. The sell-off began after the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that inflation was higher than expected in September, and extended after the Treasury Department announced weak demand for its latest auction of long-term bonds. Stocks were resilient after the initial inflation report, but were dragged lower in the afternoon as the sell-off in bonds gathered pace. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite each closed down 0.6 per cent for the day.

If they hold to maturity, then prices don‚Äôt matter.  Rates on bonds do not change.  So when a new bond is auctioned at 5%, the price of an existing bond at 4% has to drop so the total yield is 5%.  Otherwise there‚Äôd be no market for existing bonds‚Ä¶.

Just learned that holding long-term bonds can be a terrible investment. As yields rise, bond prices go down, resulting in losses for bondholders. In contrast, gold prices tend to remain steady or even rise. Plus, holding bonds becomes riskier when interest rates change. It's like having a mortgage at a low rate and then struggling to afford a new one at a higher rate. Bonds can be a trap, but gold is a safer option for steady investment. #InvestingTips #wednesdaythought

On Monday, Israel experienced financial turmoil with the shekel hitting a seven-year low, a 2% drop against the US dollar, prompting intervention by the central bank. Israel bonds saw falling prices and rising yields, and the stock market extended its 6.5% decline from Sunday, marking the worst shock since the Covid pandemic.   The turmoil is attributed to ongoing conflicts in Israel and Gaza affecting the bond market, resulting in higher bond yields and lower prices, signaling expectations of prolonged high-interest rates. While Fed sounds dovish for November, current rates will likely plateau for now.  This could mark the end of historically low 'emergency' rates seen after the Credit Crisis and further lowered during Covid.   Consequently, this will impact mortgage rates, potentially leading to more expensive loans and real estate market disruptions. High debt yields also mean increased mortgage costs for renewers, locking out first-time buyers and increasing inventory as sellers face reduced demand and have to lower prices to be able to sell.   Overall, normalized financing charges are now three times what they were 18 months ago, making high-paying, low-risk bonds an attractive option while posing challenges to real estate and mortgage markets.   In my view smart money are still on the sidelines awaiting to be deployed mostly in tech/AI market segments.

Hi SREB -- I think regardless of whether underwriters and bond rating agencies did their jobs properly, it just wasn't the Fed's job to clean up a mess -- it's just a market, and I think it's best left to its own devices without the Fed's intervention.   As for prices -- I have a hard time believing that home prices would be *higher* without Fed intervention.  Why would that be?  It's very difficult to compare the period of 1963 to the mid 1980s, which had a great deal of population and productivity growth, with the financialization that came from the mid 1980s on (including the housing bubble that grew through 2006).  I think it's also hard to compare the 1960s with the 1970s, since inflation did play a role in all prices starting in the 1970s. I think the whole point is that if the Fed had not intervened, we would be looking at a very different graph starting in 2009, and the annualized gains on those houses would have been much lower.

MORE ADVANCED REAL-ESTATE STUFF:    In theory, real-estate prices should trade in a manner that is 100% correlated to bonds...and be easy to calculate!   The price should be the "discounted value of all future potential rental cashflows"   (yes, this even applies to a principal residence because you are an equity owner who is forfeiting market rent)  Since there is no end to rental payments (cashflows).... we would call this a perpetuity. (like a pension)  Real-estate can be perpetuity because land doesn't depreciate or disappear.  Since rent increases every year, we would then call this a growing perpetuity.   Luckily, the formula for a growing perpetuity is one of the easiest in all of finance!  PV = P / (r - g)  4 numbers, thats!   PV = Present Value  P = cashflow received  r = Discount Rate / 100  g = Payment Growth Rate / 100  The discount rate (the amount of profit you demand to do the deal) in the formula could be the 10 year bond yield + risk premium AFTER COSTS. (this is called the cap rate)   So...lets try it!  Lets assume:   the rental growth rate (g) = 2.5% per year  and, you demand a 4% risk premium vs bonds for the hassle of dealing with tenants.   And lets use a home which CASHFLOWS $12,000 per year after costs, as our example.  (we ignore mortgages because this is a totally separate deal which you MAY have with a bank. Some investors dont have this cost, so its not a REAL expense)  Home price in 2021 with 0.5% 10 year bond yields:   Our demanded return is now 4.5%/yr or we would  just buy bonds.... so:   PV =  $12,000/yr / (4.5% - 2.5%)   PV = $600,000  Your home is worth 600k!   Home price in 2023 at 4.2% 10 year bond yields:  PV = $12,000/yr / (8.2% - 2.5%)  PV = $210,526.32  YOUR HOME PRICE GOT CHOPPED BY 66%   ...when bond rates rose from 0.5% to 4.2% because the asset you own STILL cashflows the SAME AMOUNT as before...  but the market can get what you're cashflowing by putting out 66% LESS money than would have been required in 2021.  In reality, real-estate is more complicated because emotion gets involved.   But in business, its just 4 numbers!  üßÇ

Gold prices touched a more than one-week high on Tuesday, a day after surging on increased market uncertainty due to the conflict in the Middle East, with dovish comments from senior Federal Reserve officials weighing on the dollar and bond yields.   Fundamentals * Spot gold rose 0.2 percent to $1,864.39 an ounce by 0117 GMT, after touching its highest level since Sept. 29 earlier. U.S. gold futures rose 0.8 percent to $1,878.20 an ounce.  * Gold prices closed about 1.6 percent higher on Monday, the biggest one-day gain in five months, as a military conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas sparked concerns that a broader conflict could affect Middle East oil supplies and boost demand for security - safe-haven assets such as gold.  * The conflict has created greater volatility for investors, adding to uncertainty ahead of the corporate earnings season and key U.S. inflation data later in the week.  * Benchmark 10-year Treasuries opened in Tokyo with the biggest gain in more than a month.  * The U.S. dollar index (.DXY) retreated after a senior Fed official said Monday that rising yields on long-term U.S. Treasuries could prompt the Fed to refrain from raising short-term policy rates further.  * Comments by Fed Vice Chairman Philip Jefferson and Dallas Fed President Lori Logan led investors to weaken the likelihood of further Fed rate hikes.  * Gold has traditionally been viewed as a safe-haven investment in times of economic uncertainty, but because it does not generate interest, it tends to lose its appeal when interest rates rise.  * SPDR Gold Trust, the world's largest publicly traded gold fund, said its holdings fell 0.5% to 861.81 tons on Monday.

Note the awful prospective return from Cash funds just 5 years ago, in 2018.   The stability and returns from cash funds now look very attractive - which is why trillions of ¬£ and $ are rushing into those funds.    The question is whether there is a risk of a second big leg down on stock market (equity) prices now?   What do the experts think?  Some say shares must fall to accommodate the the now higher *risk free* (LOL) rate on bonds.   Others say shares will fall as and when investors decide to rush back into bonds to grab the high yields now available.   But who knows?  I don't, and nor does anyone else. Very few (on the sell-side) predicted what's happening now.    What is clear, however, is that c. 13 years of zero per cent interest rates did not provide us with stability in our economy or in asset prices.   Quite the opposite in fact.  We now have severe instability.   So, be sure to learn the four point (NACK) approach to investing - and allocate your monies accordingly.   You can learn about that here.  https://paulclaireaux.com/how-much-risk-is-right-for-you/

What is a "bond vigilante?"  No, it's not Batman's nerdy cousin with a finance degree from Harvard. A bond vigilante is a buyer of bonds  who refuses to buy at current prices because they think the seller is too risky and they should pay higher interest based on the risk.

A bit dismal but this is worth reading and understanding as it applies to our current economy:  While it's generally true that government bond prices rise (and yields fall) in a weak economy on the verge of a recession, there could be scenarios where government bond prices might fall. Here are a few potential reasons:  1. **Rising Interest Rates**: If the central bank is raising interest rates to combat inflation, this could lead to falling bond prices¬≥. Higher interest rates make newly issued bonds more attractive than existing ones, leading to a decrease in the price of existing bonds¬π.  2. **Inflation Expectations**: If investors expect inflation to rise significantly in the future, they may demand higher yields to compensate for the loss of purchasing power. This would lead to falling bond prices¬≥.  3. **Increased Supply of Bonds**: If the government is issuing a large amount of debt, the increased supply could potentially lead to lower bond prices if demand doesn't keep up¬≤.  4. **Decreased Demand for Bonds**: If investors are moving their money into other types of investments (like stocks or commodities), this could decrease demand for bonds and lead to lower bond prices¬≤.  5. **Credit Risk**: If investors perceive an increased risk that the government will default on its debt, they may demand a higher yield to compensate for this risk, leading to lower bond prices¬≤.  6. **Monetary Policy Changes**: The Federal Reserve's decisions can greatly impact bond prices. For example, if the Fed decides to taper or end its bond-buying program, this could lead to lower bond prices¬π.  References:  (1) Why Is The Bond Market Down? - Forbes. https://www.forbes.com/sites/kristinmckenna/2022/02/14/why-is-the-bond-market-down/. (3) Why you should care about the global rout in government bonds. https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/04/business/global-bond-market-sell-off-explainer/index.html. üåê Impact of Decreasing Bond Prices in a Rising Interest Rate Economy: üìà  üë• For Bond Investors: Decreasing bond prices spell lower returns and higher risks. Those who bought bonds at lower rates will see their value decline with rising interest rates. They‚Äôll also face higher opportunity costs, having missed out on new bonds with higher yields, and greater inflation risk eroding their fixed income‚Äôs purchasing power. Selling bonds before maturity? Expect lower prices in the secondary market. üìâ  üíº For Bond Issuers: A scenario of decreasing bond prices means higher borrowing costs and lesser chances at refinancing. Needing to raise funds by issuing new bonds? They‚Äôll have to offer higher interest rates to attract investors, increasing their debt service burden and potentially reducing profitability. Fewer refinancing opportunities at lower interest rates will limit financial flexibility and heighten default risk. üìä  üåç For the Economy: Decreasing bond prices can be a mixed bag. On the bright side, they can signal healthy economic growth as rising interest rates reflect higher demand for money/credit, higher inflation expectations, and better returns on alternative investments - fostering consumption, investment, innovation, job creation, and income. Conversely, it might indicate a tightening monetary policy with central banks raising rates to curb inflation and prevent overheating, which could dampen economic activity by discouraging borrowing/spending and increasing capital costs for businesses and households, potentially slowing growth, reducing output/employment, and fostering financial instability. üîÑ  üîó Further Reading:  1.Bond yields & monetary policy: Investopedia 2.Economic growth & bonds: The Balance 3.Bonds, interest rates & inflation: Business Mag  üóìÔ∏è Source: Conversation with Bing, 10/5/2023  #BondMarket #InterestRates #EconomyImpact

On the other hand, optimists are paying attention to the oversold states in both bonds and stocks, the possibility of a short squeeze, a bounce back in earnings for the fourth quarter, and seasonal factors that favor the bulls. ‚ö° Oil prices crash, bond yields hold steady: A decoupling?  An Analysis:  üîπOil prices and bond yields have historically been positively correlated, meaning that they tend to move in the same direction.  üîπHowever, in recent days, oil prices have crashed sharply while bond yields have remained relatively stable. This could be a sign of a decoupling between the two asset classes.  üîπThere are a number of possible explanations for this decoupling. One possibility is that the market is anticipating a recession, which would lead to lower demand for oil and higher bond yields.   üîπHowever, another possibility is that the market is simply pricing in the fact that oil prices have become more volatile in recent months.  üîπA decoupling between oil prices and bond yields could have a number of implications. It more difficult to predict the performance of different asset classes.   üîπIt could also make it more difficult to hedge against market risk.  -- AboutBazaar

A fact: #Stocks have become more expensive vs Bonds despite the recent decline in the S&P 500 Index. and the history of this, unfortunately, does not bode well for future equity returns...  As @BobEUnlimited has pointed out, even despite equity prices falling, the magnitude of the rise in long term bond yields has meant Stocks have actually "richened" over this period, meaning their relative value has deteriorated. Below I show how this impacts future returns on investing in stocks based on 20 years of data.  The first chart demonstrates the recent "Richening" of Stocks in the form of the Equity Risk Premium. This is the difference between the earnings yield on the S&P 500 and the real 10 year Bond yield. When the ERP rises, either via an increase in the earnings yield (lower P/Es) or a fall in the real yield on bonds, stocks have "cheapened" on a relative basis - in other words they are better relative value. The opposite is true as well - when the ERP falls, stocks have richened vs Bonds. As Chart 1 shows, the increase in real yields recently, has meant the ERP has fallen, making stocks historically quite expensive vs Bonds. This is despite the index itself having fallen 8% over that period.  Buying equities when they are expensive, even on a relative basis, has a direct impact on future returns - and this is the key point of this thread. Chart 2 shows total future returns delivered by the S&P 500 index over 3mths, 6mths, 1 year and 2 years when the ERP has been in the specified bands.  The chart shows a clear correlation between higher ERP (stocks being relatively cheaper) and higher forward returns - it does pay to buy well. But more critically, with the ERP currently at 1.6%, we sit within the lowest band at the moment that has delivered negative average returns over horizons of 3, 6 and 12 months and negligible returns out to 2 years.  The 3rd exhibit tabulates the results and includes the percentage of observations in each band that are positive. It shows in the yellow highlighted band (representing the current situation) that returns are positive less than 50% of the time which is the worst expected return probability across the potential outcomes.   In other words, buying equities at the current time comes not only with a negative expected return on average across most time horizons, but with an historical probability of loss of more than 50%.  There is a lot of value in this table. For example it demonstrates how much expected returns improve as the ERP rises, allowing investors to better assess risk adjusted returns as the situation changes.  But there is one special case I have highlighted in the table thats worthy of separate discussion so investors can watch out for it should a similar opportunity arise. That is when the ERP is BELOW 1%, or even negative. This is rare - in the last 20 years it has occurred in only 6% of months. When it appears, it is usually when earnings are troughing from a deep downcycle / recession. In fact each of the instances in our sample relate to the end of the GFC market rout - from Nov-08 through Dec-09. What you can see clearly is that this actually delivered the BEST equity returns out of all the ERP bands. Stocks do not appear cheap based on the level of the ERP because trough earnings (and the earnings yield) are so far below potential earnings. However as the market and earnings rebound and the ERP itself rebounds, strong positive returns ensue.  Something to watch out for should this cycle result in a deep #recession and market rout. Every cloud has a silver lining I guess.  #macro #VIX $VIX $SPY $QQQ #SP500 #SPX

Stagflation is when the economy has high inflation and low growth. This means prices go up, but output and income go down. Stagflation is bad for the stock market, as it lowers the profits and growth of companies. Stocks and bonds both do poorly when stagflation happens. Stagflation also reduces consumer confidence and spending, which hurts the demand for goods and services. However, some stocks may do better than others in stagflation, such as defensive stocks that provide essential goods and services or value stocks that trade at low prices.  Prepare accordingly.

Imagine Japan is a big toy store. The Bank of Japan (BoJ) is like the store manager who tries to control the prices of toys. Some toys (called "bonds") have price tags that change, and the manager sets a "magic price" that they don't want the toy to go above.  Now, there are also toy coupons (called "swaps") that people trade. The price of these toy coupons is also changing. One day, the price of a 10-year toy coupon matches the "magic price" the store manager set for the bonds.  The news is saying, "Hey! The toy coupon price is now the same as the manager's magic price for the bond toy!" This is interesting because usually they're different. People are watching to see what the store manager will do next.
