Quick snapshot of everything you would like to know about "Sovereign Gold Bond Scheme (SGB)" :  1. What is Sovereign Gold Bond (SGB)? Who is the issuer?  SGBs are government securities denominated in grams of gold. They are substitutes for holding physical gold. Investors have to pay the issue price in cash and the bonds will be redeemed in cash on maturity. The Bond is issued by Reserve Bank on behalf of Government of India.  2. Why should I buy SGB rather than physical gold? What are the benefits?  The quantity of gold for which the investor pays is protected, since he receives the ongoing market price at the time of redemption/ premature redemption. The SGB offers a superior alternative to holding gold in physical form. The risks and costs of storage are eliminated. Investors are assured of the market value of gold at the time of maturity and periodical interest. SGB is free from issues like making charges and purity in the case of gold in jewellery form. The bonds are held in the books of the RBI or in demat form eliminating risk of loss of scrip etc.  3. Are there any risks in investing in SGBs?  There may be a risk of capital loss if the market price of gold declines. However, the investor does not lose in terms of the units of gold which he has paid for.  4. Who is eligible to invest in the SGBs?  Persons resident in India as defined under Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 are eligible to invest in SGB. Eligible investors include individuals, HUFs, trusts, universities and charitable institutions. Individual investors with subsequent change in residential status from resident to non-resident may continue to hold SGB till early redemption/maturity.  5. Whether joint holding will be allowed?  Yes, joint holding is allowed.  6. Can a Minor invest in SGB?  Yes. The application on behalf of the minor has to be made by his/her guardian.  7. Where can investors get the application form?  The application form will be provided by the issuing banks/SHCIL offices/designated Post Offices/agents. It can also be downloaded from the RBI‚Äôs website. Banks may also provide online application facility.  8. What are the Know-Your-Customer (KYC) norms?  Every application must be accompanied by the ‚ÄòPAN Number‚Äô issued by the Income Tax Department to the investor(s).  9. Can an investor hold more than one investor ID for subscribing to the Sovereign Gold Bond?  No. An investor can have only one unique investor Id linked to any of the prescribed identification documents. The unique investor ID is to be used for all the subsequent investments in the scheme. For holding securities in dematerialized form, quoting of PAN in the application form is mandatory.  10. What is the minimum and maximum limit for investment?  The Bonds are issued in denominations of one gram of gold and in multiples thereof. Minimum investment in the Bond shall be one gram with a maximum limit of subscription of 4 kg for individuals, 4 kg for Hindu Undivided Family (HUF) and 20 kg for trusts and similar entities notified by the government from time to time per fiscal year (April ‚Äì March). In case of joint holding, the limit applies to the first applicant. The annual ceiling will include bonds subscribed under different tranches during initial issuance by Government and those purchased from the secondary market. The ceiling on investment will not include the holdings as collateral by banks and other Financial Institutions  11. Can each member of my family buy 4Kg in their own name?  Yes, each family member can buy the bonds in his/her own name if they satisfy the eligibility criteria as defined at Q No.4.  12. Can an investor/trust buy 4 Kg/20 Kg worth of SGB every year?  Yes. An investor/trust can buy 4 Kg/20 Kg worth of gold every year as the ceiling has been fixed on a fiscal year (April-March) basis.  13. Is the maximum limit of 4 Kg applicable in case of joint holding?  The maximum limit will be applicable to the first applicant in case of a joint holding for that specific application.  14. What is the rate of interest and how will the interest be paid?  The Bonds bear interest at the rate of 2.50 per cent (fixed rate) per annum on the amount of initial investment. Interest will be credited semi-annually to the bank account of the investor and the last interest will be payable on maturity along with the principal.  15. Who are the authorized agencies selling the SGBs?  Bonds are sold through offices or branches of Nationalised Banks, Scheduled Private Banks, Scheduled Foreign Banks, designated Post Offices, Stock Holding Corporation of India Ltd. (SHCIL) and the authorised stock exchanges either directly or through their agents.  16. If I apply, am I assured of allotment?  If the customer meets the eligibility criteria, produces a valid identification document and remits the application money on time, he/she will receive the allotment.  17. When will the customers be issued Holding Certificate?  The customers will be issued Certificate of Holding on the date of issuance of the SGB. Certificate of Holding can be collected from the issuing banks/SHCIL offices/Post Offices/Designated stock exchanges/agents or obtained directly from RBI on email, if email address is provided in the application form.  18. Can I apply online?  Yes. A customer can apply online through the website of the listed scheduled commercial banks. The issue price of the Gold Bonds will be ‚Çπ 50 per gram less than the nominal value to those investors applying online and the payment against the application is made through digital mode.  19. At what price the bonds are sold?  The nominal value of Gold Bonds shall be in Indian Rupees fixed on the basis of simple average of closing price of gold of 999 purity, published by the India Bullion and Jewelers Association Limited, for the last 3 business days of the week preceding the subscription period.  20. Will RBI publish the rate of gold applicable every day?  The price of gold for the relevant tranche will be published on RBI website two days before the issue opens.  21. What will I get on redemption?  On maturity, the Gold Bonds shall be redeemed in Indian Rupees and the redemption price shall be based on simple average of closing price of gold of 999 purity of previous 3 business days from the date of repayment, published by the India Bullion and Jewelers Association Limited.  22. How will I get the redemption amount?  Both interest and redemption proceeds will be credited to the bank account furnished by the customer at the time of buying the bond.  23. What are the procedures involved during redemption?  The investor will be advised one month before maturity regarding the ensuing maturity of the bond. On the date of maturity, the maturity proceeds will be credited to the bank account as per the details on record. In case there are changes in any details, such as, account number, email ids, then the investor must intimate the bank/SHCIL/PO promptly.  24. Can I encash the bond anytime I want? Is premature redemption allowed?  Though the tenor of the bond is 8 years, early encashment/redemption of the bond is allowed after fifth year from the date of issue on coupon payment dates. The bond will be tradable on Exchanges, if held in demat form. It can also be transferred to any other eligible investor.  25. What do I have to do if I want to exit my investment?  In case of premature redemption, investors can approach the concerned bank/SHCIL offices/Post Office/agent thirty days before the coupon payment date. Request for premature redemption can only be entertained if the investor approaches the concerned bank/post office at least one day before the coupon payment date. The proceeds will be credited to the customer‚Äôs bank account provided at the time of applying for the bond.  26. Can I gift the bonds to a relative or friend on some occasion?  The bond can be gifted/transferable to a relative/friend/anybody who fulfills the eligibility criteria (as mentioned at Q.no. 4). The Bonds shall be transferable in accordance with the provisions of the Government Securities Act 2006 and the Government Securities Regulations 2007 before maturity by execution of an instrument of transfer which is available with the issuing agents.  27. Can I use these securities as collateral for loans?  Yes, these securities are eligible to be used as collateral for loans from banks, financial Institutions and Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFC). The Loan to Value ratio will be the same as applicable to ordinary gold loan prescribed by RBI from time to time. Granting loan against SGBs would be subject to decision of the bank/financing agency, and cannot be inferred as a matter of right.  28. What are the tax implications on i) interest and ii) capital gain?  Interest on the Bonds will be taxable as per the provisions of the Income-tax Act, 1961 (43 of 1961). The capital gains tax arising on redemption of SGB to an individual has been exempted. The indexation benefits will be provided to long terms capital gains arising to any person on transfer of bond.  29. Is tax deducted at source (TDS) applicable on the bond?  TDS is not applicable on the bond. However, it is the responsibility of the bond holder to comply with the tax laws.  30. Who will provide other customer services to the investors after issuance of the bonds?  The issuing banks/SHCIL offices/Post Offices/Designated stock exchanges/agents through which these securities have been purchased will provide other customer services such as change of address, early redemption, nomination, grievance redressal, transfer applications etc.  31. What are the payment options for investing in the Sovereign Gold Bonds?  Payment can be made through cash (upto ‚Çπ 20000)/cheques/demand draft/electronic fund transfer.  32. Whether nomination facility is available for these investments?  Yes, nomination facility is available as per the provisions of the Government Securities Act 2006 and Government Securities Regulations, 2007. A nomination form is available along with Application form. An individual Non - resident Indian may get the security transferred in his name on account of his being a nominee of a deceased investor provided that: "the Non-Resident investor shall need to hold the security till early redemption or till maturity; and the interest and maturity proceeds of the investment shall not be repatriable".  33. Can I get the bonds in demat form?  Yes. The bonds can be held in demat account. A specific request for the same must be made in the application form itself. Till the process of dematerialization is completed, the bonds will be held in RBI‚Äôs books. The facility for conversion to demat will also be available subsequent to allotment of the bond.  34. Can I trade these bonds?  The bonds are tradable from a date to be notified by RBI. (It may be noted that only bonds held in de-mat form with depositories can be traded in stock exchanges) The bonds can also be sold and transferred as per provisions of Government Securities Act, 2006. Partial transfer of bonds is also possible.  35. What is the procedure to be followed in the eventuality of death of an investor?  The nominee/nominees to the bond may approach the respective Receiving Office with their claim. The claim of the nominee/nominees will be recognized in terms of the provision of the Government Securities Act, 2006 read with Chapter III of Government Securities Regulation, 2007. In the absence of nomination, claim of the executors or administrators of the deceased holder or claim of the holder of the succession certificate (issued under Part X of Indian Succession Act) may be submitted to the Receiving Offices/Depository. It may be noted that the above provisions are applicable in the case of a deceased minor investor also. The title of the bond in such cases too will pass to the person fulfilling the criteria laid down in Government Securities Act, 2006 and not necessarily to the Natural Guardian.  Source : rbi.org.in

1. Treasury Prices and Yields:  Direct Impact: If the Federal Reserve commits to a specific yield target for a particular maturity of the Treasury bond, it would mean they are also implicitly controlling its price (given that bond prices move inversely to yields). If, for example, market forces start pushing the yield above the target, the Fed would intervene by purchasing the necessary amount of that bond, driving its price up and its yield down. Duration Risk: YCC can also affect yields on other maturities not directly targeted. If the Fed caps yields on the 10-year note, investors might seek better returns on longer-duration bonds (like the 30-year), pushing those yields down as well.

Thoughts about interest rates.  With bond prices falling and bond yields rising to recent highs, more are thinking that bonds are good investments. With bond yields at elevated levels, and if interest rates/bond yields eventually come down, bond prices will price, one could see capital gains as well.  Separately, bond yields are yield to maturities (YTM) on bonds, which assumes that the all future bond coupons are reinvested at the same rate as the YTM, which is fundamentally flawed because interest rates clearly do not stay constant.   At currently more elevated interest rates, the risk is for much lower interest rates, not higher. Lower interest rates lower future reinvestment rates, and overall bond returns.   Where do I see the risks given higher interest rates? Estimated ~20% are floating / ARM, and ~80% of personal mortgage loans are on fixed rate / FRM, hence the flow through from higher interest rates is only to new property buyers and existing ARM loans, thus seemingly lower impact to the consumer this time round.  Instead I see risks largely in US commercial real estate and leveraged loans, where majority is on floating rates. A higher for longer could cause far more skeletons to come out of the closet. The debt maturity wall is in 2024-2025, where lots of refinancing is required. So that timeframe bears watching.  Small banks owning a disproportionate higher amount of US commercial real estate also bears watching, and if it extends into another financial crisis again down the road. Will this time be different? Honestly, I don‚Äôt know, but just something I am keenly watching. Macro plays no broader considerations on our long-term investing strategy, but always good to be aware of what may/could happen.

Ok folks this is a üçù but getting some DMs asking about bond math so here it goes.   Given bond prices represent the present value of future cash payments (coupons + principal), the higher yields go the lower the price go. Why? Because you‚Äôre discounting those flows at a higher rate.   There are also considerations in determining the sensitivity of a bond‚Äôs price to changes in rates such as the size and frequency of the coupons. This sensitivity is called ‚Äúduration‚Äù and it is a key fixed income concept.   Regardless of a bond‚Äôs duration though, higher rates cause bond prices to fall and viceversa.   To make it more complicated, market participants use ‚Äúrates‚Äù and ‚Äúyields‚Äù differently. When traders say ‚Äúrates are rallying‚Äù they mean yields are going lower (and thus the price of bonds are going higher). This year, given the Fed‚Äôs hiking cycle, rates have ‚Äúsold off‚Äù. This means bond prices are lower given yields are higher.

Global equities saw their worst month so far this year in September, recording a decline of 4.4%. A triple-whammy of risks: rising bond yields, surging oil prices and increasing concerns about the global economic growth outlook. China momentum failed to show a material pickup, while more clouds have gathered over the Eurozone outlook. Meanwhile, geopolitical tensions continued, and the AI-fueled tech rally deflated further, taking out further steam from the equity markets.

A risk-off mood engulfed global markets in September, as central banks pressed on with the higher-for-longer narrative and the surge in oil prices further complicated the macro outlook. Both equities and bonds declined in tandem.  Energy was the only sector to close in gains for the month, while all other defensive sectors failed to provide shelter.  US equities also underperformed Europe and Asia.

Hedge funds are shorting treasuries at record levels, and the Fed is worried.  Hedge funds are making big bets using a strategy called basis trades. It exploits small differences between futures and actual bond prices.  This strategy involves shorting Treasury futures contracts and buying Treasury bonds. The Fed is concerned that this strategy could lead to disruptions in the Treasury market, especially if repo funding costs increase or interest rates drop suddenly.

Chaos In The Bond Market  Bond markets are supposed to be boring. If bonds are fun, usually it means you‚Äôre doing it wrong.  Except for last year. Bonds stopped being boring in 2022 when they started going down a lot. As their prices fell, their yields rose substantially. But yields on shorter-duration bonds (ones that mature and get paid back) rose much faster than yields on longer-duration bonds, largely because they are more under the influence of the Federal Reserve and other central banks, which control the overnight rate. In 2022, the 2 year-yield rose in anticipation of central bank hiking the overnight rate (known in the U.S. as the ‚ÄúFed Funds Rate‚Äù).  Now, it‚Äôs a completely different ball game.  Many central banks have paused or stopped raising interest rates, and some central banks are even cutting them. The market now assigns a >60% chance that the Federal Reserve is done hiking rates.  This should be good for bonds. And it is. But the chaos in the bond market continues. Why?  The first reason is that short-term yields continue to rise as expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut rates are priced out of the market. The second reason is that the U.S. government is issuing a TON of bonds to fund its fiscal deficits. Both reasons are causing bond investors lots of worry  What‚Äôs interesting is that now, unlike in 2022, yields on long-term bonds are rising more than yields on short-term bonds:  This is known as ‚Äúbear steepening‚Äù because the yield curve is steepening (long-term yields rising faster than short-term yields) and bonds are selling off (‚Äúbear‚Äù market in bonds).  Bear steepening is not very common. Often it occurs after a recession bond bull market at the beginning of a new economic cycle, such as in 2009 and 2020. This may be why bear steepeners are often quite bullish for risk assets:  Via @blockworksres

Oil Briefly touched $95 - #Europa #MarketWrap - Global bond prices fell again on Thursday, pushing the benchmark Treasury yield to a new 16-year high. The oil rally has paused, and stock markets have stabilised. - Traders are pushing yields higher on the assumption that US policymakers will maintain tight policy as oil prices fuel inflation. The 10-Yr Treasury yield increased four basis points to 4.647%. - After briefly exceeding $95 per barrel for the first time in more than a year, the US benchmark oil price settled after a drop in stockpiles at a major storage hub highlighted a widening global deficit. Stock market investors beware: stagflation is coming, and you're not ready.  If the stock market is bad now, just wait until the dollar starts falling, bonds and gold start rising, and oil prices continue to soar. That's the recipe for stagflation, a toxic economic nightmare that combines high inflation with low growth.  And very few investors are actually prepared for it.  Why stagflation is so bad for stocks  Stagflation is bad for stocks because it creates a double whammy for companies. On the one hand, their costs are going up due to inflation. On the other hand, demand for their products and services is going down due to the slowing economy.  As a result, corporate profits tend to suffer in stagflationary environments. And when corporate profits suffer, stock prices tend to follow suit.  What investors can do to prepare  If you're a stock market investor, there are a few things you can do to prepare for the possibility of stagflation:  Invest in defensive stocks. Defensive stocks are stocks of companies that sell products and services that are essential to people's everyday lives, such as food, utilities, and healthcare. These companies tend to do better in stagflationary environments because people still need their products and services even when the economy is slowing down.  Invest in real assets. Real assets, such as real estate and commodities, tend to hold up relatively well in stagflationary environments. This is because they are inflation-hedged, meaning that their value tends to rise as inflation rises.  Diversify your portfolio. Diversification is always important, but it's especially important in stagflationary environments. This is because no asset class is immune to stagflation. By diversifying your portfolio across different asset classes, you can reduce your overall risk.  Stagflation is a real threat to the stock market in the current economic environment. But by taking the steps above, investors can help to protect their portfolios from the worst effects.

üßµThread on Germany's 10-Yr Bond Yield Hitting a Decade High: üëá 1/ üìà Historical Context: The yield on Germany's 10-yr bond reaching 2.782%, its highest since July 2011, is a monumental shift. It's essential to understand that bond yields move inversely to bond prices. A rising yield typically signifies falling bond prices.  2/ üí∂ Economic Implications: This rise in yields can reflect several things: potential anticipation of inflation, expectations of tighter monetary policy by the European Central Bank (ECB), or a general shift in risk sentiment among investors.  3/ üè¶ Central Bank Decisions: The ECB, in response to changing macroeconomic conditions, might view this yield movement as a need to reconsider its policy stance. Historically low rates and quantitative easing programs could be revisited.  4/ üåç European Impact: Germany's bond market is often seen as a benchmark for Europe. A shift here can impact borrowing costs for other European nations, particularly those with weaker economies.  5/ üíº Business Environment: Higher long-term rates can translate to increased borrowing costs for companies, potentially impacting investment decisions, capital expenditure, and overall growth prospects.  6/ üè† Mortgage & Real Estate: A knock-on effect can be seen on mortgage rates. As they move up, this could temper the housing market's heat, making it more costly for consumers to finance new home purchases.  7/ üåê Global Perspective: In a globally interconnected financial system, significant yield changes in powerhouse economies like Germany can influence investor sentiment and decisions worldwide.  8/ üìä Investor Strategy: With bond prices falling (as yields rise), bond investors might need to reevaluate their portfolios. Meanwhile, the equity market can also be affected. Companies sensitive to interest rates, like those in finance or real estate, might see stock price movements.  9/ üõç Consumer Impact: If the rise in bond yields translates to higher interest rates more broadly, consumers could face higher costs on variable-rate debts, affecting disposable income and spending.  10/ üîÑ Looking Ahead: It's crucial to monitor how sustained this yield trend is. Temporary blips can be driven by short-term factors, but prolonged increases could signify structural economic shifts.  In conclusion, Germany's 10-yr bond yield hitting this decade high is more than just a statistic. It's a pulse check on economic sentiments and a precursor to potential shifts in financial strategies across Europe and beyond.   #BondYieldInsight #EconomicTrends #Trading #TradingTips #Money #Trade #Bonds

Why is it bad when the yield on bonds go up?  When the yield on bonds goes up, it can have both positive and negative implications, depending on your perspective and financial goals. Here's why some may consider it "bad" when bond yields rise:  Lower Bond Prices: Bond prices and yields have an inverse relationship. When yields go up, the prices of existing bonds with lower yields decrease. If you own these bonds and plan to sell them before maturity, you might incur a loss on your investment. This can be undesirable for investors seeking capital preservation.  Higher Borrowing Costs: Rising bond yields can lead to higher interest rates in the broader economy. This can make it more expensive for individuals and businesses to borrow money, potentially slowing down economic growth.  Stock Market Impact: Higher bond yields can make bonds more attractive compared to stocks. As a result, investors might shift their money out of the stock market and into bonds, potentially leading to a decline in stock prices. This can be seen as a negative for those heavily invested in stocks.  Impact on Homebuyers: Rising bond yields can result in higher mortgage rates, making it more expensive for people to buy homes. This can be a disadvantage for those in the housing market.  Government Debt Costs: Governments with substantial debt loads may face higher interest payments on their bonds when yields rise, potentially leading to budgetary challenges and increased taxes or reduced public services.  However, it's important to note that higher bond yields can also have positive aspects:  Better Returns for New Investors: Rising yields mean that newly issued bonds offer higher coupon rates, providing better returns for investors looking to purchase new bonds.  Inflation Hedge: Higher yields can act as a hedge against inflation. Bonds with higher yields can help protect purchasing power in an environment where prices are rising.

What's going on today with bond yields?  2y yield is down despite a hawkish Fed, while bond yields are up.  Central banks pausing -> less inflation fighting -> higher inflation risk premia -> steeper yield curves -> lower asset prices (importantly equities) -> no more hikes.  As asset prices fall, the risk of recession will increase, meaning central banks are done hiking and if anything, easing would come sooner than otherwise.  Of course the bond supply pressure is ongoing but that's not new.  It's important not to overreact to one or two days of price action, but worth thinking about these factors to be prepared for the next phase of the cycle when it comes.

A positive stock-bond correlation means that the prices of stocks and  bonds tend to move in the same direction, rising or falling together.  While this can happen, it is not the typical behavior of these asset  classes. Generally, stocks and bonds have a negative or inverse  correlation, meaning that when one goes up, the other tends to go down,  and vice versa. This negative correlation is one reason investors often  hold a mix of stocks and bonds in their portfolios to diversify and  manage risk.

Yes, typically, rising real interest rates can have a negative impact on gold prices. Real interest rates are adjusted for inflation, so when they rise, it means that the returns on interest-bearing assets like bonds become more attractive compared to holding gold, which doesn't generate interest or dividends. As a result, investors may shift their funds from gold to interest-bearing assets, leading to a decrease in demand for gold and potentially lower prices. However, it's important to note that various factors can influence gold prices, and the relationship between real rates and gold is not always straightforward.

üìä Unusual Events: Jets, Bonds, Gold, and the Fall of Rome  üìà US Bond ‚ÄòGlitch‚Äô  Yesterday morning, in what was called a ‚Äòglitch‚Äô #US bond prices spiked.¬† This happened during the Japanese market open and was later labelled a glitch, despite happening over a 3 hour window.  Some theories that have come to light  ‚ÄòIt was a glitch‚Äô #China (or someone) was selling down their bonds Unwinding of Basis trades  We look at these theories below:  üíª It was a glitch  The glitch coincided with an expiry of bond options, so some people are saying that this may have ‚Äòcaused a glitch‚Äô in the data.¬† Just to dispel this, the ‚Äòglitch‚Äô happened over 3 hours and happened over several bond denominations ‚Äì 2Y, 5Y, and 10Y, though was most pronounced in the 2 year.¬† It also happened, though less dramatically, in other bond markets like the Australian 2 Year which rose at the same time from 3.9% to 3.95% and has not seen the subsequent correction that occurred in the US.¬† If it was a ‚Äòdata glitch‚Äô why did it occur across so many markets and jurisdictions?  üá®üá≥ China (or someone else) were selling their bonds  One of the reasons you would see a spike in bonds yields is through the liquidation of bonds, i.e. selling them at a discount which has the opposite effect on yields, driving them higher.¬† It has been fairly well documented that both Saudi Arabia have reduced their US treasury holdings from $184 billion down to $108 billion, and more dramatically China, reducing their holdings from $1.3 trillion to $800 billion.¬† The recent tweets from The Kobeissi Letter show the dramatic sell down of US treasuries by some of these #BRICS countries.  Interestingly, Yellen this morning at the Clinton Global Initiative sat with Hilary Clinton discussing, among other things, China-US relations. Yellen stated that ‚ÄòIt would be disastrous for the US to decouple from China‚Äô - could this be an indication that China is decoupling from the US through the sale of US bonds and oversized purchases of #gold?  üíµ Bond basis trade  In a foreboding warning issued from the #FederalReserve researchers 5 day ago, they discussed possible ‚Äòdisruptions in US treasuries‚Äô due to an oversized fund trading position that caused a similar bond market crash back in 2020.¬†The article published by the Fed can be found here https://www.federalreserve.gov/econres/notes/feds-notes/hedge-fund-treasury-exposures-repo-and-margining-20230908.html.¬†The¬†cash-futures basis trade¬†is an arbitrage trade that involves a short Treasury futures position (currently at record highs), a long Treasury cash position, and borrowing in the repo market to finance the trade and provide leverage. These are then delivered, and the position unwound, on expiry.¬† The fact that the spike hit a level consistent with at the current Federal Reserve rate is suspicious at best and may in fact support a rapid deleveraging and Federal Reserve yield curve control to manage the situation.  üìâThe Fall of Rome  For anyone who doesn‚Äôt know about the current trend that ‚ÄòReal men think about the Fall of Rome every day‚Äô, have a look here Fall of the Roman Empire: Trend on TikTok exposes what men are really thinking | news.com.au ‚Äî Australia‚Äôs leading news site.¬†   Like we‚Äôve discussed before on Insights, sometimes you need to listen to what the whole community is telling you, and with a trend like this, there is certainly a growing ‚Äòfeeling‚Äô in the broader community that something is not quite right.  Whatever the cause of the ‚Äòglitch‚Äô, volatility in bond markets is about to increase with the Federal Reserve September interest rate decision hitting headlines this week and if there are significant movements and repositioning going on in the background, we should expect more volatility and uncertainty in the markets.   Could this have be the indicator that the inevitable credit event, ‚Äòor the fall of Rome‚Äô is about to happen?

If Bonds confuse you, read this (Bonds 101):  Generally, bond prices are inversely related to bond yields, however, the relationship is more complex when there is an inverted yield curve (where the yield on short-term bonds is higher than the yield on long-term bonds).  Bond prices can be higher or lower than their face value, depending on the demand for the bond:  1) When interest rates rise, bond prices fall. This is because investors can get a higher yield on new bonds, so they are willing to pay less for existing bonds.  2) When interest rates fall, bond prices rise. This is because investors can get a lower yield on new bonds, so they are willing to pay more for existing bonds.  3) HOWEVER, when there is an inverted yield curve, the relationship between bond yields and bond prices is more complex. This is because investors are not only looking at interest rates but also at the outlook for the economy. When investors are expecting a recession, they will be willing to pay more for bonds, even if interest rates are rising.  ‚Ä¢ For short-term bonds, bond yields & bond prices follow their typical inverse relationship   ‚Ä¢ For long-term bonds, the relationship is more complex because other factors like future economic expectations can influence demand, and therefore bond prices

The bond market wasn‚Äôt exactly in high demand for more UK government bonds at that time and so bond yields shot up and bond prices fell as investors sold off their UK government bond holdings worried that the market was about to be flooded with UK bonds.  The markets were also worried that the announcement would increase inflation and therefore force the BoE to raise rates further.  As bond yields spiked this caused an increase in collateral calls on derivatives e.g. interest rate swaps. Collateral was also requested more quickly than usual because of the rapid market movements.   Counterparty‚Äôs (often pension funds) that couldn‚Äôt meet the collateral calls were forced to sell off their government bonds. Which in turn depressed bond prices further and caused bond yields to rise even further. This is known as a feedback loop.   Hence why the BoE had to step in and start buying bonds. I don't need to call my bond desk. I understand how bond prices are related to yields. It's not rocket science.
So, bond prices and yields are not always inversely related. Sometimes, they depend on what investors expect for the future.

But long-term bonds behave differently: higher rates can mean higher prices if investors think the economy will worsen and rates will fall later. Lower rates can mean lower prices if investors think the economy will improve and rates will rise later.
In this scenario, short-term bonds still follow the usual pattern: higher rates mean lower prices and vice versa.

Interest rates affect bond prices. When rates go up, new bonds offer higher yields, so existing bonds become less attractive and their prices drop. When rates go down, new bonds offer lower yields, so existing bonds become more attractive and their prices rise.
Bond prices depend on how much investors are willing to pay for them. The more they pay, the lower the yield they get.
How bond prices and yields behave in normal and inverted markets?  Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions, but sometimes the rules change. Here‚Äôs what you need to know:
The relationship between yields and bond prices is always inverse, regardless of tenor.  But the relationship is generally more linear for short term bonds and more curved for longer term bonds.

If Bonds confuse you, read this (Bonds 101):  Generally, bond prices are inversely related to bond yields, however, the relationship is more complex when there is an inverted yield curve (where the yield on short-term bonds is higher than the yield on long-term bonds).  Bond prices can be higher or lower than their face value, depending on the demand for the bond:  1) When interest rates rise, bond prices fall. This is because investors can get a higher yield on new bonds, so they are willing to pay less for existing bonds.  2) When interest rates fall, bond prices rise. This is because investors can get a lower yield on new bonds, so they are willing to pay more for existing bonds.  3) HOWEVER, when there is an inverted yield curve, the relationship between bond yields and bond prices is more complex. This is because investors are not only looking at interest rates but also at the outlook for the economy. When investors are expecting a recession, they will be willing to pay more for bonds, even if interest rates are rising.  ‚Ä¢ For short-term bonds, bond yields & bond prices follow their typical inverse relationship   ‚Ä¢ For long-term bonds, the relationship is more complex because other factors like future economic expectations can influence demand, and therefore bond prices

The price investors are willing to pay for a bond can be significantly affected by prevailing interest rates. If prevailing interest rates are higher than when the existing bonds were issued, the prices on those existing bonds will generally fall.

That's because new bonds are likely to be issued with higher coupon rates as interest rates increase, making the old or outstanding bonds generally less attractive unless they can be purchased at a lower price. So, higher interest rates mean lower prices for existing bonds.

Yes, you are right. The traditional view of bonds as a "risk-free" asset has been upended by the recent bear market in bond prices. This has led to concerns about the impact on pensioners, who often rely on bonds for income.    There are a number of reasons why the bond market has fallen so sharply. One reason is that interest rates have been rising. As interest rates rise, the value of bonds falls, because investors demand a higher yield for holding bonds. Another reason for the decline in bond prices is that inflation has been rising. Inflation erodes the value of bonds, because the coupons paid on bonds are fixed in nominal terms.   The decline in bond prices is a major concern for pensioners, because it could lead to lower income. Pensioners often have a large portion of their assets invested in bonds, and they rely on the income from these bonds to meet their living expenses. If bond prices fall, pensioners will have to sell their bonds at a loss, which will reduce their income.    There are a number of things that pensioners can do to protect their income in a bear market.  1‚É£Diversify their portfolios, so that they are not too reliant on bonds.  2‚É£Consider investing in assets that are less sensitive to interest rates, such as stocks or real estate. 3‚É£Additionally, they can consider buying TIPS, which are Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities. TIPS are indexed to inflation, so their value will increase as inflation rises.  The recent bear market in bond prices is a reminder that no asset is truly "risk-free." Pensioners should carefully consider their investment options and make sure that they are prepared for the possibility of further declines in bond prices.

If they need to sell their bonds at a loss, they will lose money. This could make it difficult for them to maintain their standard of living in retirement.

Will be important for not only bond prices but also stock prices to see what maturities the Treasury selects to issue. The temptation will be to issue short maturities and not to pressure long dated ones with supply. Longer maturities have less liquidity and depth than Bills.  Long dated maturities impact financial asset and real estate values more than short term rates.  When recently rebuilding the TGA the Treasury overwhelmingly issued short dated paper.  Stocks were fine with the TGA rebuild issuance in part because the RRF drew down to buy that short dated paper and there was not a big liquidity drain in bonds or stocks to purchase the Treasury issued paper.  The money market funds that bought the TGA rebuild issuance and which are major RRF owners cannot buy anything but Bills and short paper.  The point?  Issuance demands are rising with both QT and expanding deficits and the Biden Treasury will do everything they can to keep rates low so not to send lower stocks and bonds and real estate going into the election.  Of course, Treasury will also put pressure on the Fed to end QT to reduce net new supply and to keep rates from running away from them.@lisaabramowicz1 @bellLantz1

üì∞ U.S. Stock Futures Lower as Rising Oil Prices Revive Inflation Concernsüìâüõ¢Ô∏è  U.S. stock index futures took a tumble on Wednesday as concerns about higher bond yields resurfaced, and soaring oil prices raised fresh inflation worries.  üìä **Stock-Index Futures Performance:**  On Wednesday, major indexes showed declines: - Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) fell 0.56% to 34,642 üìâ - S&P 500 (SPX) declined 0.42% to 4,497 üìâ - Nasdaq Composite (COMP) dropped 0.08% to 14,021 üìâ  üìà **Market Drivers:** - Investors remained cautious as benchmark Treasury yields approached multi-year highs. - Oil prices were near their 2023 peaks, with Brent crude briefly surpassing $90 per barrel. - In Europe, the Stoxx 600 index retreated due to slumping German factory orders. - Susannah Streeter, Hargreaves Lansdown's head of money and markets, noted that elevated oil prices and renewed inflation concerns were keeping market sentiment down.  üõ¢Ô∏è **Oil Prices and Inflation Worries:** - Brent crude touched $90 a barrel after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended production cuts. - The surge in energy prices raised concerns about revived inflation, potentially leading central banks to maintain higher borrowing costs. - The 10-year Treasury yield was at 4.25%, just 11 basis points below a 16-year peak.  üíº **Upcoming Events:** - Investors awaited the release of the Federal Reserve‚Äôs Beige Book at 2 p.m. Eastern. - The U.S. international trade deficit widened by 2% to $65 billion in July. - Other economic updates for the day included the final reading of the S&P U.S. services PMI for August and the ISM services report for August.  üìàüìâ **Technical Insights:** Mark Newton, head of technical strategy at Fundstrat, suggested that rising bond yields might create short-term selling pressure for U.S. stocks.
